Award.AwardTitle: RUI: The Study of Photonuclear Physics with Polarized Beams and Targets
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports research on photonuclear reactions with polarized beams and targets to investigate the properties of the nucleon and nucleon resonances with Compton scattering and to study heavy nuclei through photofission. In addition, we play a key role in the production of the HD targets used at Jefferson Lab (JLab).

The HIGS (High Intensity Gamma Source) facility at Duke University is ideal for Compton scattering from both polarized and unpolarized nucleon and nuclear targets. A comprehensive program of Compton scattering is beginning in the fall of 2013 on the proton and neutron, which will extract the electromagnetic polarizabilities with high accuracy. The ongoing program of photofission studies with polarized photons exploits the strong variation of the beam asymmetry in direct neutron production both with beam energy and with target. The proposed measurements provide a database for developing nuclear forensics and expand our understanding of this fundamental nuclear reaction.

The frozen spin HD target (HDIce) will be used in three "A" rated experiments at JLab after the facility upgrade. The high purity gas used in all these targets will be purified at JMU. Commercial gas that is 98% HD is distilled at low temperature to separate the remaining H2 and D2 and produce gas for making targets with very long spin relaxation times. Recent upgrades to the distillery permit the production of gas with H2 and D2 impurities much lower than previously obtained leading to higher quality targets for the next round of experiments. Existing gas stores are sufficient to produce the required gas.

Undergraduate students will be involved in all aspects of this research and will gain experience in nuclear experiments and detectors, data analysis, and applications of nuclear physics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant has enabled continued participation in the experiments at JLab involving the frozen spin HD ice target and participation in a series of experiment with low-energy polarized gamma ray executd at Duke University at the High Intensity Gamma source (HIGS) Facility.

 

The contributions to the polarized target program at JLab involved the purification and assay of HD gas for use in producing the HDice target. This involved the low-termperature distillation of a mizture of HD, H2 and D2 to produce very high purity HD gas. The purity was determined by measuring the relative content of H2 and D2 in the gas using gas chromatography. This method provides a lower detection limit of roughly 1 part in a 1000. Collaborators are able to use Raman scattering to reduce the sensitivity to 1 part in 10^6. This combination of techniques permits both the rapid assay fo the gas puty on site and a detailed examination of the purity for use in preparing targets.

 

Thanks to the work done at JMU on the purification of HD gas, a new distillery has been constructed to take advantage of the experience obtained operating the current device. This new equipment will be operated by collaborators at the University of Rome.

 

The work at Duke involved measurement of photo nuetron raction on a vareity of targets in the energy region roughly below the two neutron threshold. These reaction, using linearly polarized photons exhibit sensitivity to the direction the neutrons are emitted relative to the polarization plane. This has proven useful in discriminating fissile and non-fissile materials. In addition, a cryogenic hydrogen target developed at Duke has been used to study Compton scattering from both liquid H2 and D2 target. This work is on-going.

 

JMU undergraduates have been involved in all aspects of the program. Several papers were presented by JMU students on the photoneutron and Compton scattering program at Duke. Much of the work done in the distillery lab and all of the gas chromatography was done by undergraduates. These sctivities played a significant role,in boosting interest in nuclear science at JMU and have resulted in strong interest in courses in nuclear and particle physics. This sustained interest in nuclear science has helped promote the development of anew nuclear physics laboratory on-campus to open in 2017. This facility will house clinical x-ray and gamma-ray machinces for use in undergraduates experimental programs.
